description: Passing through East Canton and heading toward Minerva in Stark County, drivers along the Lincoln Highway are treated to slices of pastoral beauty and the occasional relic barn with a Mail Pouch advertisement. And as Ohio continues to reopen businesses during the COVID-19 pandemic, traffic is rising as evidenced by numbers from the Ohio Department of...
text:
Passing through East Canton and heading toward Minerva in Stark County,
drivers along the Lincoln Highway are treated to slices of pastoral beauty and
the occasional relic barn with a Mail Pouch advertisement.

Near Robertsville, the stretch of curves and bends offers a detour from the
byway onto Baywood Street SE.

Tires roll over an ancient brick stretch of the fabled artery -- distinguished
as the country's first transcontinental highway, from New York City to San
Francisco.

The automotive stroll is an example of the many scenic byways and routes
crossing the state map.

And as Ohio continues to reopen businesses during the COVID-19 pandemic,
traffic is rising as evidenced by numbers from the Ohio Department of
Transportation.

"My family and I and some other friends of ours .. we've been going out and
doing scenic drives," said Jim Cassler, of Canton. "The Lincoln Highway is a
great place to go.

"You can see the old brick stretches," said Cassler, who serves on the board
of directors for the Ohio Lincoln Highway Heritage Corridor.

"There's a stretch north of Mansfield and also in Upper Sandusky, so there's a
number of brick stretches you can visit, and there is a short section, Sylvan
Road, in Wooster."

ODOT spokesman Matt Bruning said the overall driving spike isn't a surprise.
It's expected to continue unless there's a setback or backtracking on health-
related restrictions.

After traffic numbers "bottomed out" in mid-April, "we're starting to see a
very slow but steady rebound," said Bruning, the agency's press secretary.

By the numbers

Statewide traffic data reflects the tightening and easing of the stay-at-home
order issued near the end of March by Gov. Mike DeWine.

From March 15 to 21, statewide traffic decreased 30 percent compared to a year
earlier, with Northeast Ohio registering a 31 percent dip.

A plunge was recorded from March 22 to 28, with traffic down 46 percent, both
across Ohio and in the Canton-Akron region.

Traffic patterns held steady here and elsewhere on average until peaking at a
roughly 49 percent weekly decrease from April 5 to 11, according to ODOT.

The numbers show a cause and effect: As salons, restaurants, offices, retail
stores and other businesses continue to open, Ohioans are getting behind the
wheel more frequently.

"We're slowly ticking back to normal levels where we would expect to be,"
Bruning said.

"How will it look three months from now or six months from now until a year
from now, it's anybody's guess," he added. "This is certainly an unprecedented
time."

Scenic drives

Practical transportation, however, isn't the only function of Ohio's roads.
There's a rich network of historic routes and eye-pleasing byways, Bruning
noted.

"I have a family of five," he said. "... It is not uncommon for us to jump in
the car and enjoy some of the scenery."

Advising that residents should follow the pandemic-related directives of
DeWine and state health officials, Bruning said, that "as long as you're being
safe, (road trips are) a great way to see and learn something about the
state."

Here's a a handful of Ohio's most scenic routes:

Lincoln Highway: Representing the first roadway system in support of cars, the
Lincoln was conceived in 1913 as the first highway from the Atlantic to the
Pacific.

The Lincoln Highway Historic Byway (240 miles in Ohio) follows the final
alignment adopted in 1928, linking the cities of Canton, Massillon, Wooster,
Mansfield, Bucyrus, Upper Sandusky, Delphos and Van Wert.

Heritage Corridors of Bath: Connecting 19th century hamlets with the Hale Farm
and Village, the Bath Nature Preserve and Cuyahoga Valley National Park, it's
best accessed by taking Interstate 77 to Ghent Road (exit 138), turning north
onto Ghent Road, which ends at Cleveland-Massillon Road.

Amish Country Byway: 160-mile route featuring Holmes and Knox counties,
rolling hills, sprawling vistas, historic sites, scenic rivers, the state's
longest covered bridge and restaurants specializing in Amish country cooking.

Johnny Appleseed Historic Byway: Stretching more than 30 miles along Route 39
between Mansfield and Loudonville and Route 603 between the village of Mifflin
and Malabar Farm.

Attractions include historic sites linked to John "Appleseed" Chapman.

Ohio & Erie Canalway: Tracing the story of the Ohio & Erie Canal and following
a general path from Dover to Cleveland.

About 20 miles travels directly through Cuyahoga Valley National Park. Sights
include farm fields, nature preserves, river corridors, bridges, smokestacks
and canal remnants.

Historic National Road: Dating to the early 19th century, the Ohio portion
covers 225 miles, extending from the West Virginia state line at the Ohio
River to the Indiana state line.

Most of the alignment was incorporated into U.S. 40 when the national route
system went into effect in the 1920s.

Hocking Hills: A 26-mile byway following state Route 374 through the natural
beauty of Hocking Hills and around Hocking State Forest.

For more information on the routes, visit:

https://​ohio.gov/​wps/​portal/​gov/​site/​tourism/​resources/​scenic-byways

Scenery and history

Cassler said logging miles on the Lincoln Highway is especially rewarding
during a time of uncertainty.

"I think it's more enjoyable now just because it's one of the few things you
can do to get out and see things without having to go into places that are
closed and restricted," he said. "The scenery is always going to be there, and
the murals, the roads and things, they can't take those away."

Beyond the fabled Lincoln Highway, Cassler said other gems abound throughout
Ohio.

"I think no matter where you are in the state, there's one of those fairly
close to you and they all offer scenery and history and interesting things to
do no matter what time of year or where you go."

CREDIT: ED BALINT

title: Scenic Ohio drives offer pandemic getaways
html:
Passing through East Canton and heading toward Minerva in Stark County, drivers along the Lincoln Highway are treated to slices of pastoral beauty and the occasional relic barn with a Mail Pouch advertisement.

Near Robertsville, the stretch of curves and bends offers a detour from the byway onto Baywood Street SE.

Tires roll over an ancient brick stretch of the fabled artery — distinguished as the country’s first transcontinental highway, from New York City to San Francisco.

The automotive stroll is an example of the many scenic byways and routes crossing the state map.

And as Ohio continues to reopen businesses during the COVID-19 pandemic, traffic is rising as evidenced by numbers from the Ohio Department of Transportation.

“My family and I and some other friends of ours .. we’ve been going out and doing scenic drives,” said Jim Cassler, of Canton. “The Lincoln Highway is a great place to go.

“You can see the old brick stretches,” said Cassler, who serves on the board of directors for the Ohio Lincoln Highway Heritage Corridor.

“There’s a stretch north of Mansfield and also in Upper Sandusky, so there’s a number of brick stretches you can visit, and there is a short section, Sylvan Road, in Wooster.”

ODOT spokesman Matt Bruning said the overall driving spike isn’t a surprise. It’s expected to continue unless there’s a setback or backtracking on health-related restrictions.

After traffic numbers “bottomed out” in mid-April, “we’re starting to see a very slow but steady rebound,” said Bruning, the agency’s press secretary.

By the numbers

Statewide traffic data reflects the tightening and easing of the stay-at-home order issued near the end of March by Gov. Mike DeWine.

From March 15 to 21, statewide traffic decreased 30 percent compared to a year earlier, with Northeast Ohio registering a 31 percent dip.

A plunge was recorded from March 22 to 28, with traffic down 46 percent, both across Ohio and in the Canton-Akron region.

Traffic patterns held steady here and elsewhere on average until peaking at a roughly 49 percent weekly decrease from April 5 to 11, according to ODOT.

The numbers show a cause and effect: As salons, restaurants, offices, retail stores and other businesses continue to open, Ohioans are getting behind the wheel more frequently.

“We’re slowly ticking back to normal levels where we would expect to be,” Bruning said.

“How will it look three months from now or six months from now until a year from now, it’s anybody’s guess,” he added. “This is certainly an unprecedented time.”

Scenic drives

Practical transportation, however, isn’t the only function of Ohio’s roads. There’s a rich network of historic routes and eye-pleasing byways, Bruning noted.

“I have a family of five,” he said. “... It is not uncommon for us to jump in the car and enjoy some of the scenery.”

Advising that residents should follow the pandemic-related directives of DeWine and state health officials, Bruning said, that “as long as you’re being safe, (road trips are) a great way to see and learn something about the state.”

Here’s a a handful of Ohio’s most scenic routes:

Lincoln Highway: Representing the first roadway system in support of cars, the Lincoln was conceived in 1913 as the first highway from the Atlantic to the Pacific.

The Lincoln Highway Historic Byway (240 miles in Ohio) follows the final alignment adopted in 1928, linking the cities of Canton, Massillon, Wooster, Mansfield, Bucyrus, Upper Sandusky, Delphos and Van Wert.

Heritage Corridors of Bath: Connecting 19th century hamlets with the Hale Farm and Village, the Bath Nature Preserve and Cuyahoga Valley National Park, it’s best accessed by taking Interstate 77 to Ghent Road (exit 138), turning north onto Ghent Road, which ends at Cleveland-Massillon Road.

Amish Country Byway: 160-mile route featuring Holmes and Knox counties, rolling hills, sprawling vistas, historic sites, scenic rivers, the state’s longest covered bridge and restaurants specializing in Amish country cooking.

Johnny Appleseed Historic Byway: Stretching more than 30 miles along Route 39 between Mansfield and Loudonville and Route 603 between the village of Mifflin and Malabar Farm.

Attractions include historic sites linked to John “Appleseed” Chapman.

Ohio & Erie Canalway: Tracing the story of the Ohio & Erie Canal and following a general path from Dover to Cleveland.

About 20 miles travels directly through Cuyahoga Valley National Park. Sights include farm fields, nature preserves, river corridors, bridges, smokestacks and canal remnants.

Historic National Road: Dating to the early 19th century, the Ohio portion covers 225 miles, extending from the West Virginia state line at the Ohio River to the Indiana state line.

Most of the alignment was incorporated into U.S. 40 when the national route system went into effect in the 1920s.

Hocking Hills: A 26-mile byway following state Route 374 through the natural beauty of Hocking Hills and around Hocking State Forest.

For more information on the routes, visit:

https://​ohio.gov/​wps/​portal/​gov/​site/​tourism/​resources/​scenic-byways

Scenery and history

Cassler said logging miles on the Lincoln Highway is especially rewarding during a time of uncertainty.

“I think it’s more enjoyable now just because it’s one of the few things you can do to get out and see things without having to go into places that are closed and restricted,” he said. “The scenery is always going to be there, and the murals, the roads and things, they can’t take those away.”

Beyond the fabled Lincoln Highway, Cassler said other gems abound throughout Ohio.

“I think no matter where you are in the state, there’s one of those fairly close to you and they all offer scenery and history and interesting things to do no matter what time of year or where you go.”

CREDIT: ED BALINT
